name: Hagia Sophia
description: The Great Church of Constantinople, built by Emperor Justinian I. The largest cathedral in the world for nearly a thousand years. Converted to a mosque in 1453 after the fall of Constantinople.

name: St. Peter's Basilica
description: One of the four major basilicas of Rome, built over the tomb of St. Peter. The current basilica was constructed in the 16th-17th centuries, replacing the original Constantinian basilica.

name: Archbasilica of St. John Lateran
description: The cathedral of the Diocese of Rome and the official ecclesiastical seat of the Pope. One of the four major basilicas of Rome, originally built by Constantine the Great.

name: Basilica of St. Paul Outside the Walls
description: One of the four major basilicas of Rome, built over the tomb of St. Paul the Apostle. Originally constructed by Constantine the Great.

name: Basilica of St. Mary Major
description: One of the four major basilicas of Rome, dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary. Built by Pope Sixtus III after the Council of Ephesus.

name: Church of the Holy Sepulchre
description: The most important church in Christianity, built over the sites of Christ's crucifixion and resurrection. Constructed by Constantine the Great and his mother St. Helena.

name: Basilica of the Nativity
description: Built over the traditional site of the Nativity of Jesus Christ. Constructed by Constantine the Great and his mother St. Helena.

name: Basilica of San Vitale
description: One of the most important examples of early Christian Byzantine art and architecture in Western Europe. Built during the reign of Justinian I, famous for its mosaics.

name: Basilica of Sant'Apollinare Nuovo
description: Built by the Ostrogothic King Theodoric the Great as his palace chapel. Contains some of the finest Byzantine mosaics in Western Europe.

name: Basilica of St. Ambrose
description: One of the oldest churches in Milan, built by St. Ambrose, Bishop of Milan. A masterpiece of Lombard Romanesque architecture.

name: Basilica of St. Lawrence Outside the Walls
description: One of the seven pilgrimage churches of Rome, built over the tomb of St. Lawrence, one of the first seven deacons of Rome. Originally constructed by Constantine the Great.

name: Basilica of St. Clement
description: Dedicated to Pope Clement I, the third successor of St. Peter. Built over an earlier church and Roman buildings, with remarkable archaeological layers.

name: Basilica of St. Denis
description: The first major structure built in the Gothic style. The burial place of French kings and the traditional burial site of St. Denis, the patron saint of France.

name: Canterbury Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archbishop of Canterbury, leader of the Church of England. Founded by St. Augustine of Canterbury, site of the martyrdom of St. Thomas Becket.

name: Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi
description: The mother church of the Roman Catholic Order of Friars Minor Conventual. Built over the tomb of St. Francis of Assisi, contains important frescoes by Giotto.

name: Aachen Cathedral
description: The oldest cathedral in northern Europe, built by Charlemagne as his palatine chapel. The coronation church for German kings for 600 years.

name: Church of the Holy Apostles
description: The second-most important church in Constantinople after Hagia Sophia. Built by Constantine the Great to house relics of the Apostles. Destroyed after the Ottoman conquest.

name: Cathedral of St. Sophia
description: The first site in Ukraine to be inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List. Built by Yaroslav the Wise, it remains the main cathedral of the Ukrainian Orthodox Church.

name: Basilica of St. Sebastian Outside the Walls
description: One of the seven pilgrimage churches of Rome, built over the catacombs where St. Sebastian was buried. Originally constructed by Constantine the Great.

name: Basilica of the Holy Cross in Jerusalem
description: One of the seven pilgrimage churches of Rome, built to house relics of the True Cross brought from Jerusalem by St. Helena, mother of Constantine the Great.

name: Old St. Peter's Basilica
description: The original basilica built by Constantine the Great over the tomb of St. Peter. Demolished in the 16th century to make way for the current St. Peter's Basilica.

name: Basilica of St. Praxedes
description: Built by Pope Paschal I to house relics of early Christian martyrs. Contains magnificent 9th-century mosaics, including the famous mosaic of Pope Paschal I.

name: Basilica of St. Mary in Trastevere
description: One of the oldest churches in Rome, possibly the first church where Mass was openly celebrated. Contains important 12th-century mosaics.

name: Basilica of St. Pudenziana
description: One of the oldest places of Christian worship in Rome, built over a 2nd-century Roman house. Contains the oldest apse mosaic in Rome.

name: Basilica of St. Sabina
description: An early Christian basilica on the Aventine Hill, one of the best-preserved examples of early Christian architecture. Famous for its 5th-century carved wooden doors.

name: Abbey of Monte Cassino
description: The first Benedictine monastery, founded by St. Benedict of Nursia. The birthplace of Western monasticism, destroyed and rebuilt several times throughout history.

name: Basilica of St. Martin
description: Built over the tomb of St. Martin of Tours, one of the most popular saints in medieval Europe. A major pilgrimage destination for centuries.

name: Basilica of St. Sernin
description: The largest remaining Romanesque building in Europe, a major stop on the Way of St. James pilgrimage route. Built to house relics of St. Saturninus.

name: Cologne Cathedral
description: A masterpiece of Gothic architecture, one of the largest cathedrals in Europe. Built to house the relics of the Three Magi, it took over 600 years to complete.

name: Basilica of St. Anthony of Padua
description: One of the eight international shrines recognized by the Holy See. Built to house the tomb of St. Anthony of Padua, one of the most popular saints.

name: Cathedral of St. Mary of the See
description: The largest Gothic cathedral in the world and the third-largest church overall. Built on the site of a former mosque after the Reconquista.

name: Basilica of St. John
description: Built by Emperor Justinian I over the traditional tomb of St. John the Apostle. One of the largest churches of the Byzantine Empire, destroyed by Tamerlane.

name: Basilica of St. Demetrius
description: The main sanctuary dedicated to St. Demetrius, the patron saint of Thessalonica. One of the most important pilgrimage sites in the Byzantine Empire.

name: Basilica of St. Mark
description: The cathedral church of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Venice. Famous for its opulent design, gilded mosaics, and status as a symbol of Venetian wealth and power. Built to house the relics of St. Mark the Evangelist.

name: Church of St. Trophimus
description: A Romanesque church and former cathedral, famous for its elaborate portal sculptures. Part of the Arles, Roman and Romanesque Monuments UNESCO site.

name: Primatial Basilica of St. John
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Lyon, seat of the Primate of Gaul. A masterpiece of Gothic architecture, built over several centuries.

name: Fulda Cathedral
description: The abbey church of Fulda Abbey, one of the most important monasteries in medieval Germany. Contains the tomb of St. Boniface, the Apostle of Germany.

name: St. Vitus Cathedral
description: The metropolitan cathedral of Prague, a prominent example of Gothic architecture. The spiritual symbol of the Czech state and burial place of Bohemian kings.

name: St. Stephen's Cathedral
description: The mother church of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Vienna and the seat of the Archbishop. A symbol of Vienna and one of the most important Gothic structures in Austria.

name: Basilica of Bom Jesus
description: A Jesuit church and UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contains the mortal remains of St. Francis Xavier, one of the greatest missionaries in Church history.

name: Basilica of St. Nicholas
description: Built in Bari to house the relics of St. Nicholas of Myra (Santa Claus), brought from Myra in 1087. An important pilgrimage site for both Catholics and Orthodox Christians. The crypt contains the saint's relics.

name: Church of the Holy Apostles (Old)
description: The original Church of the Holy Apostles built by Constantine the Great. Replaced by Justinian's larger church in 536. Contained the relics of the Apostles and served as the imperial mausoleum.

name: Basilica of St. Mary in Cosmedin
description: A medieval church famous for the Bocca della Verità (Mouth of Truth) in its portico. Originally built in the 6th century, rebuilt in the 8th century. Known for its beautiful Cosmatesque floor.

name: Basilica of Santi Cosma e Damiano
description: Built by Pope Felix IV in the Forum of Peace, incorporating a Roman temple. Famous for its 6th-century apse mosaic, one of the finest examples of early Christian art in Rome.

name: Basilica of St. Cecilia
description: Built over the house of St. Cecilia, the patron saint of music. Contains the famous statue of St. Cecilia by Stefano Maderno and important 9th-century mosaics.

name: Basilica of St. Agnes Outside the Walls
description: One of the seven pilgrimage churches of Rome, built over the catacombs of St. Agnes. Originally constructed by Constantine the Great, rebuilt in the 7th century. Contains the relics of St. Agnes.

name: Basilica of St. Pancras
description: One of the oldest churches in Rome, built by Constantine the Great over the tomb of St. Pancras, a 14-year-old martyr. Located on the Via Aurelia.

name: Cathedral of St. Peter
description: The ancient cathedral of Antioch, traditionally the first place where followers of Jesus were called 'Christians' (Acts 11:26). The See of Antioch, one of the five patriarchates.

name: Cathedral of St. Mark
description: The ancient cathedral of Alexandria, traditionally founded by St. Mark the Evangelist. The See of Alexandria, one of the five patriarchates of the Pentarchy.

name: Cathedral of St. John the Theologian
description: The early Christian cathedral of Ephesus, where St. John the Evangelist is said to have lived and written his Gospel. Replaced by the larger Justinianic basilica in 536.

name: House of the Virgin Mary
description: A shrine built after the Council of Ephesus (431) which declared Mary the Theotokos (Mother of God). Located near Ephesus, traditionally believed to be where the Virgin Mary spent her last years.

name: Basilica of St. Denis (Original)
description: The original Merovingian basilica built over the tomb of St. Denis, the patron saint of France. Replaced by the current Gothic basilica in the 12th century.

name: Basilica of St. Martin (Original)
description: The original basilica built over the tomb of St. Martin of Tours. One of the most important pilgrimage destinations in medieval Europe. Destroyed during the French Revolution.

name: Basilica of St. Remigius
description: A Romanesque basilica in Reims, built to house the relics of St. Remigius, who baptized Clovis, the first Christian king of the Franks. The coronation church of French kings.

name: Chartres Cathedral
description: A masterpiece of French Gothic architecture, famous for its stained glass windows and labyrinth. Built to house the Sancta Camisia, the tunic of the Virgin Mary.

name: Reims Cathedral
description: The coronation cathedral of France, where most French kings were crowned. A masterpiece of High Gothic architecture, famous for its sculptures and stained glass.

name: Notre-Dame de Paris
description: One of the finest examples of French Gothic architecture. The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Paris, famous for its rose windows, flying buttresses, and gargoyles.

name: Salisbury Cathedral
description: A masterpiece of Early English Gothic architecture. Houses the best-preserved of the four surviving copies of the Magna Carta. Has the tallest church spire in the United Kingdom.

name: York Minster
description: One of the largest Gothic cathedrals in Northern Europe. The seat of the Archbishop of York, second only to Canterbury in the Church of England hierarchy.

name: Lincoln Cathedral
description: Once the tallest building in the world (until 1549). A masterpiece of English Gothic architecture, famous for its three towers and the Lincoln Imp.

name: Durham Cathedral
description: A masterpiece of Norman architecture and the first building in the world to use a stone rib vault. Houses the shrine of St. Cuthbert and the tomb of the Venerable Bede.

name: Wells Cathedral
description: The first cathedral in England to be built in the Gothic style. Famous for its West Front with 300 medieval statues and its unique scissor arches.

name: Speyer Cathedral
description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site and the largest Romanesque church in the world. The burial place of eight German emperors and kings. A symbol of imperial power.

name: Worms Cathedral
description: One of the finest examples of Romanesque architecture in Germany. The site of the Diet of Worms (1521) where Martin Luther was called to account for his teachings.

name: Mainz Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Mainz, one of the most important archbishoprics in the Holy Roman Empire. A Romanesque cathedral with later Gothic additions.

name: Trier Cathedral
description: The oldest cathedral in Germany, built by Constantine the Great. Houses the Holy Tunic, believed to be the seamless garment of Christ. A UNESCO World Heritage Site.

name: Bamberg Cathedral
description: A Romanesque cathedral and UNESCO World Heritage Site. Contains the tomb of Pope Clement II, the only pope buried north of the Alps. Famous for the Bamberg Rider statue.

name: Naumburg Cathedral
description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site, famous for its 13th-century sculptures by the Naumburg Master, particularly the statues of Uta and Ekkehard. A masterpiece of Gothic art.

name: Magdeburg Cathedral
description: The first Gothic cathedral in Germany, built over the tomb of St. Maurice. The burial place of Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor. Contains important medieval sculptures.

name: Ulm Minster
description: The tallest church in the world (161.5m). A masterpiece of Gothic architecture, built by the citizens of Ulm as a symbol of their wealth and independence.

name: Regensburg Cathedral
description: The only Gothic cathedral in Bavaria. A masterpiece of High Gothic architecture, famous for its stained glass windows and the Laughing Angel sculpture.

name: Freiburg Minster
description: A masterpiece of Gothic architecture, famous for its 116-meter tower and beautiful stained glass windows. The only major Gothic cathedral completed in the Middle Ages.

name: Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela
description: The destination of the Way of St. James, one of the most important Christian pilgrimages. Built over the tomb of St. James the Apostle. A UNESCO World Heritage Site and masterpiece of Romanesque architecture.

name: Toledo Cathedral
description: The primate cathedral of Spain, a masterpiece of Gothic architecture. Contains important works by El Greco and houses the largest collection of relics in Spain.

name: Burgos Cathedral
description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site and masterpiece of Spanish Gothic architecture. The burial place of El Cid and his wife. Famous for its ornate spires and star-vaulted ceiling.

name: León Cathedral
description: Known as the 'House of Light' for its extensive stained glass windows, covering 1,800 square meters. A masterpiece of French-style Gothic architecture in Spain.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of the Pillar
description: The first church dedicated to the Virgin Mary, built on the site where she is said to have appeared to St. James the Apostle. One of the most important Marian shrines in Spain.

name: Santa Maria de Montserrat
description: A Benedictine abbey and one of Spain's most important pilgrimage sites. Houses the Black Madonna of Montserrat, the patron saint of Catalonia.

name: Florence Cathedral
description: A masterpiece of Italian Gothic and Renaissance architecture. Famous for Brunelleschi's dome, Giotto's bell tower, and its polychrome marble facade.

name: Siena Cathedral
description: A masterpiece of Italian Romanesque-Gothic architecture. Famous for its black and white striped marble, Piccolomini Library, and the works of Donatello and Michelangelo.

name: Pisa Cathedral
description: Part of the Piazza dei Miracoli UNESCO World Heritage Site. A masterpiece of Pisan Romanesque architecture, famous for its bronze doors and pulpit by Giovanni Pisano.

name: Orvieto Cathedral
description: A masterpiece of Italian Gothic architecture, famous for its polychrome facade and Signorelli's frescoes of the Last Judgment. Built to house the Corporal of Bolsena.

name: Basilica of St. Mary of the Angels
description: Built to enclose the Porziuncola, the small chapel where St. Francis received his calling. Also contains the Cappella del Transito where St. Francis died.

name: Basilica of the Holy House
description: Built to house the Holy House of Nazareth, believed to be the house where the Virgin Mary lived and where the Annunciation occurred. One of the most important Marian shrines.

name: Jasna Góra Monastery
description: The most important Catholic pilgrimage site in Poland. Houses the Black Madonna of Częstochowa, the Queen of Poland. A symbol of Polish national identity and faith.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Częstochowa
description: The main church of the Jasna Góra Monastery complex, built to accommodate the millions of pilgrims who visit the Black Madonna icon.

name: Wawel Cathedral
description: The coronation and burial site of Polish kings. Houses the relics of St. Stanislaus, the patron saint of Poland. A symbol of Polish statehood and Catholicism.

name: Gniezno Cathedral
description: The first capital of Poland and the seat of the Primate of Poland. Contains the relics of St. Adalbert, the first patron saint of Poland. The coronation church of Polish kings.

name: Esztergom Basilica
description: The largest church in Hungary and the seat of the Primate of Hungary. Built on the site of the first Hungarian cathedral. Contains the Bakócz Chapel, a masterpiece of Renaissance art.

name: St. Stephen's Basilica
description: The largest church in Budapest, dedicated to St. Stephen, the first king of Hungary. Houses the Holy Right, the mummified right hand of St. Stephen.

name: Cathedral of the Assumption
description: The cathedral of Oradea, Romania. A masterpiece of Baroque architecture, built on the site of an earlier Romanesque cathedral. An important center of Catholicism in Transylvania.

name: Ljubljana Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Ljubljana, Slovenia. A Baroque masterpiece with beautiful frescoes and the famous bronze doors commemorating Slovenian history.

name: Zagreb Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Zagreb, Croatia. A Gothic cathedral with Neo-Gothic additions. The tallest building in Croatia and a symbol of Croatian Catholicism.

name: Cathedral of St. Domnius
description: The oldest Catholic cathedral in the world still in use in its original structure. Built as the mausoleum of Emperor Diocletian, converted to a cathedral in the 7th century.

name: Dubrovnik Cathedral
description: A Baroque cathedral built on the site of earlier churches. Houses relics of St. Blaise, the patron saint of Dubrovnik. Part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site of Dubrovnik.

name: Roman Catholic Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bucharest, Romania. A Neo-Romanesque church, one of the few Catholic cathedrals in predominantly Orthodox Romania.

name: Riga Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Latvia. Originally Catholic, it became Lutheran during the Reformation. One of the largest medieval churches in the Baltic states.

name: Vilnius Cathedral
description: The main Catholic cathedral of Lithuania. The coronation church of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania. Contains the tomb of St. Casimir, the patron saint of Lithuania.

name: St. John's Archcathedral
description: The oldest church in Warsaw and the coronation church of Polish kings. Destroyed and rebuilt multiple times, most recently after World War II. A symbol of Polish resilience.

name: Wawel Cathedral (Kraków)
description: The coronation and burial site of Polish kings. Houses the relics of St. Stanislaus and St. Hedwig. A symbol of Polish statehood and Catholicism.

name: Helsinki Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland. Originally Catholic, it became Lutheran during the Reformation. A Neoclassical masterpiece dominating Helsinki's skyline.

name: Stockholm Cathedral
description: The oldest church in Stockholm, originally Catholic, now Lutheran. The coronation and wedding church of Swedish monarchs. Contains the famous St. George and the Dragon sculpture.

name: Oslo Cathedral
description: The main church of the Church of Norway (Lutheran). Originally Catholic, it became Lutheran during the Reformation. The coronation church of Norwegian kings.

name: Church of Our Lady
description: The cathedral of Copenhagen, originally Catholic, now Lutheran. The coronation church of Danish kings. Contains the famous statues of Christ and the Apostles by Thorvaldsen.

name: Uppsala Cathedral
description: The largest cathedral in Scandinavia. Originally Catholic, it became Lutheran during the Reformation. The coronation church of Swedish kings and the burial place of Swedish monarchs.

name: Turku Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Finland. Originally Catholic, it became Lutheran during the Reformation. The mother church of the Finnish Lutheran Church.

name: St. James's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Riga, Latvia. A Brick Gothic masterpiece. One of the few Catholic cathedrals in the Baltic states.

name: St. Mary's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Estonia. Originally Catholic, it became Lutheran during the Reformation. The oldest church in Tallinn.

name: St. Henry's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Helsinki, Finland. A Neo-Gothic church, one of the few Catholic cathedrals in predominantly Lutheran Finland.

name: St. Eric's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Stockholm, Sweden. A Neo-Gothic church, one of the few Catholic cathedrals in predominantly Lutheran Sweden.

name: St. Olav's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Oslo, Norway. A Neo-Gothic church, one of the few Catholic cathedrals in predominantly Lutheran Norway.

name: St. Ansgar's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Copenhagen, Denmark. A Neo-Gothic church, one of the few Catholic cathedrals in predominantly Lutheran Denmark.

name: Uppsala Catholic Church
description: A Catholic church in Uppsala, Sweden. One of the few Catholic churches in predominantly Lutheran Sweden, serving the small Catholic community.

name: Turku Catholic Church
description: A Catholic church in Turku, Finland. One of the few Catholic churches in predominantly Lutheran Finland, serving the small Catholic community.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Guadalupe
description: The most visited Catholic pilgrimage site in the Americas. Built on the site where Our Lady of Guadalupe appeared to St. Juan Diego. The new basilica was completed in 1976 to accommodate millions of pilgrims.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Aparecida
description: The largest Marian shrine in the world and the second-largest basilica after St. Peter's. Built to house the image of Our Lady of Aparecida, the patroness of Brazil. Receives millions of pilgrims annually.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Fatima
description: One of the most important Marian shrines in the world, built on the site where Our Lady appeared to three shepherd children in 1917. A major pilgrimage destination, receiving millions of visitors annually.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Lourdes
description: One of the most important Marian pilgrimage sites in the world. Built on the site where Our Lady appeared to St. Bernadette Soubirous in 1858. The grotto and healing spring attract millions of pilgrims seeking physical and spiritual healing.

name: Basilica of the Annunciation
description: Built over the traditional site of the Annunciation, where the Angel Gabriel announced to Mary that she would bear the Son of God. The largest Christian church in the Middle East, incorporating earlier churches dating back to the 4th century.

name: Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception
description: The largest Catholic church in North America and one of the ten largest churches in the world. The national shrine of the United States, dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary under her title of the Immaculate Conception.

name: Basilica of St. Mary
description: The first basilica in the United States, designated in 1926. A masterpiece of Beaux-Arts architecture, it serves as the co-cathedral of the Archdiocese of St. Paul and Minneapolis.

name: Cathedral Basilica of St. Louis
description: The mother church of the Archdiocese of St. Louis. Famous for its extensive collection of mosaics, one of the largest in the Western Hemisphere, covering over 83,000 square feet.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of the Rosary of Manaoag
description: One of the most important Marian shrines in the Philippines. The image of Our Lady of Manaoag is believed to be miraculous and draws millions of pilgrims annually. The basilica was elevated to minor basilica status in 2015.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Africa
description: A Neo-Byzantine basilica overlooking the Bay of Algiers. Built by French colonists, it is one of the most important Catholic churches in North Africa. The basilica houses a black Madonna statue, mirroring Our Lady of Africa.

name: Basilica of the Sacred Heart
description: A massive Art Deco basilica, one of the largest churches in the world by volume. Built to commemorate the 75th anniversary of Belgian independence. The National Basilica of Belgium.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Knock
description: Built on the site where Our Lady, St. Joseph, and St. John the Evangelist appeared to villagers in 1879. One of the most important Marian shrines in Ireland, attracting over a million pilgrims annually.

name: Basilica of the Sacred Heart
description: A Romanesque-Byzantine basilica, one of the largest churches in Canada. Built by the Congregation of Holy Cross, it serves as a shrine and a place of pilgrimage. Known for its beautiful dome and mosaics.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Peace
description: The largest church in the world by area. Built by President Félix Houphouët-Boigny of Ivory Coast, it is modeled after St. Peter's Basilica in Rome. A symbol of peace and unity in Africa.

name: Church of St. Mary of Zion
description: The most important church in Ethiopia, believed to house the Ark of the Covenant. The original 4th-century church was rebuilt in the 17th century. A central site of Ethiopian Orthodox Christianity.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Lebanon
description: A Maronite Catholic basilica and major pilgrimage site in Lebanon. The shrine features a large bronze statue of the Virgin Mary overlooking the Mediterranean Sea. A symbol of Lebanese Christianity and unity.

name: Basilica of Our Lady Help of Christians
description: Also known as Sheshan Basilica, the most important Catholic pilgrimage site in China. Built on Sheshan Hill, it houses a statue of Our Lady of Sheshan, the patroness of China. A symbol of Chinese Catholicism.

name: Basilica of the Twenty-Six Holy Martyrs
description: Built on the site where 26 Christians were martyred in 1597, including St. Paul Miki. Commemorates the persecution of Christians in Japan. The church was destroyed by the atomic bomb in 1945 and rebuilt.

name: Basilica of St. Josaphat
description: A stunning example of Polish Cathedral style architecture, built by Polish immigrants. One of the most beautiful churches in the United States, modeled after St. Peter's Basilica in Rome.

name: Basilica of St. Stanislaus Kostka
description: The first Polish parish in Chicago and one of the largest Polish churches in the United States. A masterpiece of Polish Cathedral style architecture, serving the Polish-American community.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Perpetual Help
description: Also known as the Mission Church, a Redemptorist church famous for its healing ministry. One of the most visited Catholic shrines in the United States, attracting thousands of pilgrims seeking healing.

name: Basilica of St. Joseph
description: A historic German Catholic church in Detroit, known for its beautiful architecture and rich history. Serves as a symbol of the German immigrant community in the city.

name: Basilica of St. Anne de Beaupré
description: One of the oldest and most important pilgrimage sites in North America. Built on the site where St. Anne is said to have appeared. Receives over a million pilgrims annually, many seeking healing.

name: Basilica of St. Patrick's Old Cathedral
description: The first Catholic cathedral in New York City, built when anti-Catholic sentiment was strong. A symbol of Irish Catholic presence in America and a historic landmark in Lower Manhattan.

name: Basilica of St. Michael
description: The largest Renaissance church north of the Alps. Built by the Jesuits as a symbol of the Counter-Reformation. Contains the crypt of the Wittelsbach dynasty and is a masterpiece of German Renaissance architecture.

name: Basilica of St. Thomas
description: Built over the traditional tomb of St. Thomas the Apostle, who is said to have brought Christianity to India. One of the most important pilgrimage sites in India, attracting Christians from around the world.

name: Basilica of St. Andrew
description: The largest church in Greece and one of the largest in the Balkans. Built to house the relics of St. Andrew the Apostle, the patron saint of Greece. A modern architectural masterpiece.

name: Basilica of St. Peter
description: A Gothic church in Cologne, originally built as a collegiate church. Known for its beautiful architecture and as the burial place of St. Peter of Alcantara. Part of Cologne's rich ecclesiastical heritage.

name: Cathedral Basilica of St. Matthew the Apostle
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Washington and the site of many important Catholic ceremonies, including the funeral Mass of President John F. Kennedy. A prominent landmark in the nation's capital.

name: Basilica of St. Luke
description: A Romanesque basilica in Padua, originally built to house the relics of St. Luke the Evangelist. Known for its beautiful frescoes and as an important pilgrimage site in northern Italy.

name: Basilica of St. Bartholomew on the Island
description: Built on Tiber Island, one of Rome's most historic locations. Houses relics of St. Bartholomew the Apostle and serves as a memorial to modern martyrs. A symbol of ecumenical dialogue.

name: Basilica of St. Philip Neri
description: Also known as the Chiesa Nuova, built for St. Philip Neri's Oratorians. A masterpiece of Baroque architecture, containing important works of art and the tomb of St. Philip Neri, the Apostle of Rome.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Ta' Pinu
description: The national shrine of Malta, built on the site where Our Lady appeared to a Maltese woman in 1883. One of the most important Marian shrines in the Mediterranean, attracting pilgrims from around the world.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Good Health
description: Also known as the Lourdes of the East, one of the most important Marian shrines in India. Built on the site where Our Lady appeared to a Hindu boy and a Portuguese sailor. Attracts millions of pilgrims annually.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of La Vang
description: The most important Marian shrine in Vietnam, built on the site where Our Lady appeared to persecuted Vietnamese Catholics in 1798. A symbol of Vietnamese Catholicism and resilience under persecution.

name: Basilica of the National Shrine of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary
description: The first Catholic cathedral built in the United States after the nation's founding. Designed by Benjamin Henry Latrobe, it is a masterpiece of Neoclassical architecture and a symbol of religious freedom in America.

name: Cathedral Basilica of Saints Peter and Paul
description: The largest Catholic church in Pennsylvania and the principal church of the Archdiocese of Philadelphia. A masterpiece of Roman-Corinthian architecture, built during the height of the Catholic population growth in America.

name: Basilica of St. Francis Xavier
description: A beautiful Gothic Revival basilica in rural Iowa, built by German immigrants. Known for its stunning architecture and as the site of the famous Field of Dreams movie location. A testament to immigrant faith and perseverance.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Luján
description: The most important Marian shrine in Argentina and one of the most visited in South America. Built to house the image of Our Lady of Luján, the patroness of Argentina. Receives millions of pilgrims annually.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Chiquinquirá
description: The most important Marian shrine in Colombia, built to house the miraculous image of Our Lady of Chiquinquirá, the patroness of Colombia. A major pilgrimage destination and symbol of Colombian Catholicism.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Copacabana
description: The most important Marian shrine in Bolivia, built on the shores of Lake Titicaca. Houses the image of Our Lady of Copacabana, the patroness of Bolivia. A major pilgrimage site combining Catholic and indigenous traditions.

name: Cathedral Basilica of St. Paul
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Melbourne, Australia. A masterpiece of Gothic Revival architecture, built during the gold rush era. The largest church in Australia and a symbol of Irish Catholic presence.

name: St. Mary's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Sydney and the seat of the Archbishop of Sydney. A masterpiece of Gothic Revival architecture, the largest church in Australia. Built by Irish Catholic immigrants.

name: Myeongdong Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Seoul and the first Gothic church in Korea. A symbol of Korean Catholicism and a site of historical significance during the Korean War. The mother church of Korean Catholicism.

name: Assumption Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Bangkok and the principal church of Catholicism in Thailand. Built by French missionaries, it serves the small but vibrant Catholic community in predominantly Buddhist Thailand.

name: Regina Mundi Catholic Church
description: The largest Catholic church in South Africa, known as the 'People's Church' for its role in the anti-apartheid struggle. A symbol of resistance and hope, where many anti-apartheid meetings were held.

name: St. Mary's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Cape Town, the oldest Catholic cathedral in South Africa. Built during the British colonial period, it serves as the mother church of South African Catholicism.

name: Holy Family Basilica
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Nairobi and the largest Catholic church in Kenya. Built by the Holy Ghost Fathers, it serves as the mother church of East African Catholicism and a symbol of the growing Church in Africa.

name: Basilica of the Sacred Heart of Jesus
description: A modern basilica in Warsaw, built in the interwar period. A symbol of Polish Catholicism and resilience, heavily damaged during World War II and rebuilt. Serves as a parish church and pilgrimage site.

name: St. Joseph's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bucharest, Romania. A Neo-Gothic church built during the Austro-Hungarian period, serving the small but significant Catholic community in predominantly Orthodox Romania.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Sorrows
description: A Servite basilica in Chicago, known for its beautiful architecture and devotion to Our Lady of Sorrows. A major pilgrimage site, especially during Holy Week, attracting thousands of faithful.

name: Basilica of St. Adalbert
description: A historic basilica in Essen, Germany, originally built as a collegiate church. Known for its Romanesque architecture and as the burial place of St. Adalbert of Prague. Part of Essen's rich ecclesiastical heritage.

name: Basilica of St. Wenceslas
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Olomouc, Czech Republic. Originally built as a Romanesque basilica, rebuilt in Gothic style. Houses the remains of St. Wenceslas and is a symbol of Czech Catholicism.

name: Basilica of St. George
description: The oldest surviving church building in Prague Castle complex. A Romanesque basilica dedicated to St. George, containing important medieval frescoes and the tombs of early Bohemian rulers.

name: St. Stephen's Basilica
description: The largest church in Budapest, dedicated to St. Stephen, the first king of Hungary. Houses the Holy Right, the mummified right hand of St. Stephen. A masterpiece of Neoclassical architecture and symbol of Hungarian Catholicism.

name: St. Mary's Basilica
description: A Brick Gothic basilica in Kraków's Main Square, famous for its wooden altarpiece by Veit Stoss and the hourly trumpet call from its tower. One of Poland's most important churches and a symbol of Polish national identity.

name: St. Mary's Church
description: The largest brick church in the world. A masterpiece of Brick Gothic architecture, built by the Hanseatic League. The main church of Gdańsk, Poland, and a symbol of the city's medieval prosperity.

name: Trier Cathedral
description: The oldest cathedral in Germany, built by Constantine the Great. Houses the Holy Tunic, believed to be the seamless garment of Christ. A UNESCO World Heritage Site and symbol of early Christianity in Germany.

name: Basilica of St. Mary Star of the Sea
description: The oldest Catholic church in Melbourne, Australia. Built by Irish immigrants during the gold rush, it serves as a symbol of the early Catholic presence in Australia and the Irish diaspora.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of the Rosary
description: Also known as the Church of Santo Domingo, one of the most important churches in Lima, Peru. Houses the remains of St. Rose of Lima, the first saint of the Americas. A masterpiece of colonial architecture.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of Charity
description: The national shrine of Cuba, built to house the image of Our Lady of Charity of El Cobre, the patroness of Cuba. A symbol of Cuban Catholicism and national identity, attracting pilgrims from around the world.

name: St. Joseph's Oratory
description: The largest church in Canada and one of the largest in the world. Built by St. Brother André, it is a major pilgrimage site dedicated to St. Joseph. The dome is the third-largest of its kind in the world.

name: St. Patrick's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Diocese of Auckland, New Zealand. Built by Irish Catholic immigrants, it is the oldest Catholic church in New Zealand and a symbol of the early Catholic presence in the country.

name: Sacred Heart Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Wellington, New Zealand. A beautiful Gothic Revival church, serving as the mother church of New Zealand Catholicism and the seat of the Archbishop.

name: St. Joseph's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Diocese of Dunedin, New Zealand. A Gothic Revival church built by Scottish and Irish immigrants, representing the Catholic presence in the South Island of New Zealand.

name: St. Mary's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Perth, Australia. A Gothic Revival church built during the gold rush era, serving as the mother church of Western Australia and a symbol of Irish Catholic presence.

name: St. Francis Xavier's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Adelaide, Australia. A Gothic Revival church built by German and Irish immigrants, serving as the mother church of South Australia.

name: St. Stephen's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Brisbane, Australia. A Gothic Revival church built during Queensland's early settlement, serving as the mother church of Queensland Catholicism.

name: Cathedral of the Good Shepherd
description: The oldest Catholic church in Singapore and the cathedral of the Archdiocese of Singapore. Built by French missionaries, it serves the diverse Catholic community in this multicultural city-state.

name: Jakarta Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Jakarta, Indonesia. Also known as the Church of Our Lady of the Assumption, it is the seat of the Archbishop of Jakarta and serves the Catholic community in predominantly Muslim Indonesia.

name: Manila Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Manila, Philippines. Also known as the Minor Basilica of the Immaculate Conception, it has been rebuilt eight times due to earthquakes and wars. The mother church of the Philippines.

name: Basilica of Our Lady of the Rosary of Pompeii
description: A major Marian shrine in Italy, built near the ruins of ancient Pompeii. Founded by Blessed Bartolo Longo, it houses the famous image of Our Lady of the Rosary and attracts millions of pilgrims annually.

name: Holy Cross Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Lagos, Nigeria. Built during the British colonial period, it serves as the mother church of Nigerian Catholicism and a symbol of the growing Church in West Africa.

name: Notre-Dame du Congo
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of the Congo. A modern basilica serving as the mother church of Congolese Catholicism and a symbol of the vibrant Church in Central Africa.

name: Holy Spirit Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Accra, Ghana. A modern church built after Ghana's independence, serving as the mother church of Ghanaian Catholicism and a symbol of the growing Church in West Africa.

name: Cathedral of Our Lady of Victories
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Dakar, Senegal. Built during the French colonial period, it serves as the mother church of Senegalese Catholicism and a symbol of the Catholic presence in predominantly Muslim West Africa.

name: Cathedral of St. Vincent de Paul
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Tunis, Tunisia. Built during the French colonial period, it serves the small Catholic community in predominantly Muslim Tunisia and is a symbol of interfaith dialogue.

name: Sacred Heart Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Rabat (located in Casablanca), Morocco. A masterpiece of Art Deco architecture, built during the French protectorate. Now serves as a cultural center, symbolizing the Catholic presence in predominantly Muslim Morocco.

name: Cathedral of Our Lady of Egypt
description: The cathedral of the Coptic Catholic Church in Cairo, Egypt. Also known as the Cathedral of the Nativity, it serves the Coptic Catholic community and is a symbol of the ancient Christian presence in Egypt.

name: St. Michael's Cathedral
description: The cathedral of the Archdiocese of Toronto, Canada. A Gothic Revival church built by Irish immigrants, serving as the mother church of Ontario Catholicism and a symbol of the Irish Catholic presence in Canada.
